newsitem.title: CHINA: Shanghai copper futures end down on profit-taking.
newsitem.headline: Shanghai copper futures end down on profit-taking.

text.p: Shanghai copper futures ended down across the board on Thursday on profit-taking, traders said.
The most actively traded October 1997 contract ended at an intraday low of 23,450 yuan ($2,828) per tonne, losing 50 yuan. It opened at 23,500 and hit a high of 23,600.
July lost 20 to 22,800 yuan, August 100 to 23,020, September 80 to 23,230, November 30 to 23,520 and December 50 to 23,550.
Combined volume rose to 38,760 tonnes from 24,460.
Copper opened slightly up on speculative buying but profit-taking at higher levels pushed prices down for most of the session.
Traders said retail investors dominated today's trading, offsetting their long positions due to the uncertain short-term market trend.
"Many investors liquidated their long positions built a few days ago due to uncertainties about the market trend," one trader said.
"Institutional investors are cautious about coming in right now, which indicates a consolidation period," he said.
The price of physical copper is around 22,800 yuan in the Shanghai area and is likely to fall in the near future due to weak demand, traders said.
Aluminium ended mostly up. July was unchanged at 14,300 yuan per tonne, August did not trade, September rose 70 to 14,580, October 60 to 14,650 and November fell 330 to 14,620.
Combined volume rose to 950 tonnes from 810.
